Finally, I felt someone's cold touch on me. I turned abruptly and saw behind me dozens of black figures stretching out clawed hands toward me. Some of them had burned faces.
WrittenText_WolfSonVardhal_03_3: I guess the proximity of the ruins and the tales I had heard were starting to do the trick!
WrittenText_Hershlik_FocusStone_2: The strange stone that fell into my hands during an ill-fated trip to Khorinis appears to be more than an ordinary mineral. While the rays of the sun reflect off its lake-smooth surface, the light of the moon seems to penetrate its unbroken texture, making its interior pulsate and constantly change shape! I am certain that this stone has not been crafted or shaped by time. Later today, I will take it to a friendly mage. Perhaps his knowledge will reveal secrets that the oldest books in Waldfried are silent about.
WrittenText_BermarJournal_2: It looks like Lorenzo finally convinced me to leave Laran. In his last letter to me, he wrote that it’s no longer safe to travel by the sea, and ‘His royal prickness, Rhobar, will soon seize all my caravels’. I took only necessities with me. And Kyle. Maybe on Archolos, this layabout will learn something, and one day be worthy to call himself my son.
WrittenText_BermarJournal_4: I took a single glance at the farm Lorenzo told me about, and I couldn’t get myself together once I saw all this mess. The mill is about to collapse. Field raiders are ravaging the fields, and a local creek is filled with mud. I think I got myself into bloody trouble...
WrittenText_BermarJournal_6: I just got back from the talks with Marcello, the owner of this shithole. It looks like he’ll sell me the farm for a symbolic crate of wine. Lorenzo promised to send me his men to help, but I know how this help is going to be like. They do more harm than good! It’s time to look for workers on my own.
WrittenText_BermarJournal_8: Finding a reliable worker these days is almost impossible. My employees are nothing more than a bunch of slackers. Except for Willem. At least he forces those bastards to work. Thanks to his discipline and Lorenzo’s mercenaries, I got rid of all the beasts from the fields. Maybe there’s still hope for this place.
WrittenText_BermarJournal_New_2: All it took was a single spark and the old mill caught fire. Lorenzo sent me today another miller, Joris. He seems like an honest and knowledgeable man. He says that the soil near the descent to the sea is right for building a new mill. In the morning, I’ll send him to the town for materials and a few men.
WrittenText_BermarJournal_New_4: Wings of the new mill flap smoothly and farmers bring crates full of vegetables. That’s music to my ears. The only thing that doesn’t let me sleep is this stubborn boy. If he doesn't work, I’ll make him volunteer as a digger at the Valley of Mines. Maybe this little trip will make him a man!
WrittenText_BermarJournal_New_6: Last night, farmers saw rats as big as wolves on one of the fields. Hod was meant to take a look at it, but he got drunk, like he always does. This time he spoke some bullshit about an orc he saw behind the farm. Enough is enough. Tonight, I will tell Willem to cut his pay and spill all that grog away!
WrittenText_BermarJournal_New_8: Hod was found dead in the nearby bushes. He got drunk again, fell off the cliff and became a dinner for scavengers. It looks like I’ll have to make an expense and find a replacement for him. What’s worse, Joris seems to believe in this fairytale. Did all the people on this island go mad?
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_01_1: This summer, like the one before it, and even, as elders say, the summer before that, crops were not big and fish were not biting well. The sky was pouring down day by day, night by night. And on this sorrowful hour, a Foregin King has arrived at the shore with a hundred of his men, armed as for war. He was a greedy and haughty man, and the life of others meant as much as the lives of meatbugs he crushed under his feet.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_01_2: And so the King of Slaves got off his crimson boat over the heads of his servants. He breathed heavily, for he was a man of grand posture. He looked around on the left and right, hoping to see a song-worthy battle.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_01_3: But instead of people preparing for a fight, the Warlord saw only a scrawny old man and three younglings behind him, clutching on wicker baskets filled with gifts.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_01_4: The old man hoped that the tributes would suffice the Foreign King, so he would refrain from violence. The Proud Sovereign looked at the gifts laid before him, snorted with contempt, and tossed them away with his fat hand. He demanded that each of the younglings bring him the greatest treasure of this land, and if he won’t be happy of them, he promised that the darkness of Morgrad itself shall fall upon them.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_02_1: The first youngling approached the Foregin King, and with trembling hands he offered him a necklace made of polished amber. The Sovereign climbed down his slaves like a fat molerat from his den. He then yanked the necklace from the boy’s hands and tried to put it through his head. But with the first attempt, the trinket broke and ambers fell one after another into the sand. The Wrathful One grabbed the boy in half and choked him to death with the strap left in his hands.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_02_2: The second youngling offered the Cruel One the best wine on the island. Impatient to wait until the boy poured the drink into a goblet, the Foregin King snatched the jug and drank it eagerly.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_02_3: But as soon as he emptied it, he threw it up. Then, the Conqueror angered greatly, and ordered his grunts to fill the boy with wine until it spilled out of his ears.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_02_4: The third youngling, however, brought no gift with him, so the Foreign King pointed at one of his lapdogs to punish him for this insult. When the shadow of death hanged cruelly above the poor boy, he promised to lead the Greedy King to the true treasure of this land. Amused, but also curious, he rushed after the youngling and both disappeared in the darkness of the mountain grotto.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_03_1: After delving through twisted, salt-soaked corridors, the Foregin King reached the end of the cave, but no treasure was to be seen. The Terrible One then angered greatly at the boy, grabbed him by his throat, and shook, nearly choking the whole life out of him. The Youngling then pointed with a shaking finger at the silver rocks glimmering in darkness, and the Greedy King rejoiced a hundred-fold.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_03_2: Soon the Arrogant One called all of his men and ordered them to dig as long as all the riches of the mountain would be extracted. The boy disappeared, but the king barely noticed that for the visions of immeasurable treasures and power blot his eyes entirely.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_03_3: After the last rock barring the entrance to the silvery reward was cast aside, something swooshed, howled, and rumbled in the depths, and a gigantic mass of water washed away the small and baffled King-Fool and his cowardly grunts.
WrittenText_SilbachLegend_03_4: And so the story comes to an end. Nyordek the Imp punished the Foregin King, and the Silver Creek flows on the island to this day.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_01_1: For many years, scholars and simple men could not decide what is the true treasure of Archolos. Some say it is wine. In the company of this beverage, countless treaties were signed, kings crowned and wars declared. Others would say that it is gold. After all, due to merchant contracts, the island is now called ‘Vengard of the East’. For me, however, that treasure has always been silver.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_01_2: Legends tell that many years before robbers, traders and lords tore apart the goods of this island, mountain caves were teeming with an immense source of silver. Eventually, the greed of some foreign king led to a landslide,
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_01_3: due to which, silver ore fragments fell into a creek below.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_01_4: In such a way, people started to name it ‘Silver Creek’, and in its basin, the village of Silbach was built.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_01_5: Old merchant documents from that period confirm that the village was the place for unloading silver. There was so much of this raw material around, that people would call Silbach the ‘Silver Court’. Raftsmen would carry immeasurable amounts of silver ore to the town and to the mouth of the river. It was silver that made Silbach flourish and turned it into one of the key transit points on Archolos.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_02_1: The earliest records about Silbach suggest that the village could be built in the period following the arrival of Maximus III, king of Myrtana. According to oral traditions, however, the settlement existed already before the time of the coming of ‘iron-clad warriors from beyond the great sea’. Presumably, Silbach was then nothing more than a bunch of huts which due to the flourishing trade grew to the size of a regular village.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_02_2: After Maximus’s invasion, the town of Archolos was turned into a ruin, and its reconstruction to a Myrtanian-styled city lasted many years. At this time, Silbach, situated in the centre of the island, became the main trade point on the island.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_02_3: Although due to the king's reforms, the old order was rooted out from the town, traditions found their way to flourish outside it. Despite being a part of the Kingdom of Myrtana, Silbach became a refuge for local habits.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_02_4: There is no doubt that through nurturing memories of the old times, villagers speak so proudly of their land and crops it gives birth to. But they also scorn townsfolk, whom they call ‘a rotten fruit of traitors and foreign aggressors’.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_03_1: One day I met a farmer, a mage and an alchemist. All of them had their theory explaining the fertility of the soil around Silbach. The farmer claimed that villagers learnt how to tame the forces of nature with their hard work. The mage, however, believed that the gratitude belongs to Adanos who in his generosity regularly brings rain upon the fields. The alchemist, on the other hand, stated that the volcanic soils increase the growth of crops.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_03_2: Perhaps only one of them was right, all, or no one. Each of them, however, agreed that sooner or later Silbach will become torn apart by different factions battling over its wealth.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_03_3: Looking at the village today, I can say that they were right. Araxos Guild ceaselessly sends their scouts to herd wild beasts near the village, so later they can gloriously come to villagers’ rescue and bound them with lifetime contracts. Wolf Sons, however, tend to threaten and remind them about historical affiliations.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_03_4: This jostling is carefully watched by Godfrey, the governor of Archolos, who introduced the vassal system. From the most honoured people of Silbach, he chose the man whom he gave the noble title and the village together with the areas around it. The price for such a gift, however, was meant to be a boundless service to the crown.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_04_1: Sir Bodryn, also called ‘Nestor’, was the first ruler of Silbach. As the governor expected, he faithfully served the authorities of the town, often fulfilling the whims of townsfolk while disregarding the needs of his own people. Some say it was the reason why no chronicle ever mentioned his name.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_04_2: After Bodryn’s death, his son, Sir William, took the rulership over Silbach. On the first day of his governance, he visited the church in the town where he swore service to Archolos and Myrtana. His rule was a constant struggle for keeping the balance between the needs of townsfolk and villagers.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_04_3: One summer, William was taken by the plague which broke out on the island. His son, Ramsey, was then but a youngling, so he remained under the custody of his mother. Thus, Lady Aldona, also called an ‘Iron Lady’, took control over Silbach, and no ruler was ever close to her grandeur and determination.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_04_4: Despite the governor's orders, Aldona built a large manor in Silbach, renewed the chapel of Adanos, and erected a watermill solely for villagers. For this and other reasons, she was brought to the town hall to explain herself. But  ‘whenever Lady Aldona spoke, the governor and his lapdogs looked beside her like a bunch of scared little rats’.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_05_1: Lady Aldona ruled Silbach wisely, and many people speak highly of her even today. No lord before her had enough courage to stand in opposition to governors and fight for the good of the people of Silbach. After Ramsey came of age, his mother, until the end of her days, remained at his side, advising him in political and economical matters.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_05_2: Sir Ramsey took the place of Lady Aldona when he finished 24 springs and rules the village till this day. The people of Silbach, however, don’t find in him the strength of his mother nor the peace of his father. Year after year, he is more like his grandfather, both in appearance and character.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_05_3: Today, governor Morris, decided to take advantage of Ramsey’s passion for hunting and allowed him to organise yearly ventures across the island. Having tasted lavish town life, year after year Ramsey more and more scarcely visits his home village.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_05_4: Many people of Silbach wished to rise against Ramsey, but the governor had a plan for it. In the place of the lord, a village elder named Albyn, stepped in. His iron rules successfully quench voices of rebellion.
WrittenText_SilbachBackstory_05_5: The question remains, however, for how long?
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_01_1: No. Don't count on me to describe to you in detail how I ended up on Archolos. The story sounds as amazing as it is pathetic, and I happen to have a reputation to uphold. However the gracious winds brought me from the far south to this exotic land northeast of the Sea of Myrtana. Were it not for a contract with a friendly merchant family, I would probably have nothing to look for here. In fact, I'm guessing the locals wouldn't even let me into the harbor tavern!
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_01_2: Archolos is an old country with a rich history, of which the native inhabitants are often and eagerly reminded.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_01_3: Strangers tend to be unwelcome here - especially the penniless and the newcomers from the Southern Islands. If you're a Southerner, you have a problem. If you are a poor Southerner, you have a double problem. Fate had never spared me gold in my life, so at least having no roof over my head and dying of hunger were not a threat.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_01_4: Taking advantage of my free time, I decided to write a few words about the island and its inhabitants. Who knows, maybe they will save you a few problems?
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_02_1: The first and most obvious point of my trip was the city. The truth was told by sailors about the size of this agglomeration. It is huge! Its countless streets, passageways, arcades and overpasses are sure to make you dizzy.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_02_2: Whether you've been here for a while or not, I advise you to buy Cartographer's Ludwig's city map, with key directional points marked on it. If you still get lost, ask any of the Araxos Merchant's Guild runners for directions. They will lead you anywhere you want - of course, if you toss them a few coins beforehand.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_02_3: Archolos is a city of many possibilities, but it is just as easy to get a blade under your ribcage here if you are not careful. Once you've made your way through the throngs of workers and poor in the harbor, stop by the Siren's Wail for a pint of ale. Helga, the tavern's owner, may serve nasty beer, but she's also a treasure trove of gossip and information.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_02_4: The most important thing is to find a job. Even if it's carrying barrels of rotten fish, you have to work in this town. Otherwise, sooner or later you will end up on the street, and from there you will take a straight path to the Poorhouse. And believe me, you don't want to end up there.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_03_1: Prepare yourself, dear reader, for the inhabitants of this village to be only slightly nicer than a herd of angry scavengers! They will stare you down, spit at your feet and threaten with their fists - especially Gabrien. Day and night he guards some shed like a rabid dog guards a piece of rotten meat. I had the impression that he didn't beat my face in just because he didn't want to listen to the lamentations of the steward later on.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_03_2: Albyn, the Village Elder, is the voice of the people of Silbach, so don't expect a warm welcome from him. Before he lets you speak, he will recite a whole litany of rights and duties.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_03_3: If you want to live in harmony with him, you'd better take his words to heart. He's a strict man, but he appreciates hard work in people. Impress him and you will earn his respect.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_03_4: I stayed at Bastian's inn and even got warm food there. He's probably the most decent man I've met in the village. He cares about his guests no matter who they are or where they come from. As long as they have something to pay for it. He helped me with the local drunkard Rik. If he hadn't done that, I'm sure I would have been in chains. If you can survive in Silbach, I give you my word, you will survive anywhere on this island!
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_04_1: After reaching Archolos I asked the carrier to drop me off at the northeastern beach called by the locals 'Amber Coast'. At first, the guy was a bit annoyed, but a few extra coins settled the matter. Anything to avoid paying that horrendous duty!
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_04_2: As soon as I stepped ashore, the fishermen working there gave me unfriendly glances. All except Duncan. The man handed me grog and offered to take me stealthily into harbor. I declined out of common sense, though he sounded like an honest man.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_04_3: I had a completely different impression when talking to people on the west coast. The settlement managed by Zachary called 'Sailor's Retreat' is a real oasis of peace. The fishermen there, former sailors of the Myrtanian fleet, live from day to day, practicing simple but honest crafts.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_04_4: Zachary is a man of principle, with great faith in the law. He also has big knowledge of history. If you have some time, sit by his campfire and listen to some stories. His friend Harold collects and sells various trinkets thrown ashore by the waves. Although most of that is junk, sometimes you can find a real beauty.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_05_1: To the southwest of Sailor's Retreat, you'll find a farm owned by the landowner, Bermar. Its inhabitants value hard work and are clearly proud of it. Unlike those in Silbach, they will welcome you with open arms - as long as your presence does not become a burden.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_05_2: Despite the fact that the farm is surrounded by woods from all sides and there is only one road leading to it, the people seem unconcerned about bandits and wild animals.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_05_3: One of the workers, named Hod, claims that this is due to 'divine intervention' and the fact that the locals live in harmony with nature. I find it hard to believe the words of a guy who never parts with a bottle of grog.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_05_4: Bermar is the complete opposite of his employees. He is a nervous and abrasive man, especially towards his son, Kyle, whom he constantly rushes to work. On the other hand, I even understand him. Managing a farm operation is a big responsibility. Despite his sharp tongue, Bermar commands respect from people. Apparently he also maintains good relations with the merchant guild Araxos, whose mercenaries often visit the farm.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_06_1: While on Archolos, it would be a sin not to visit its famous vineyards that produce arguably the best wine in the world. There are two grape farms on the island, one in the north near the town and one in the south near the village. Each is characterized by a different work policy and, of course, the taste of the wine produced.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_06_2: The northern vineyard, managed by a certain Valerio, produces strong and expressive wines that directly reach the tables of the richer part of society. Although the owner has many years on his neck, he still vigorously fulfills his duties.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_06_3: In his work he is helped by his two sons, who, to put it lightly, are not in love with each other. I swear that when the old man dies, knives will be drawn between the brothers.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_06_4: The southern vineyard is run by a rival winemaking family - the Arrazola family. They produce light and sweet wines, contrasting with the heavy, aromatic drinks of the competitor from the north. It was their liquors that appealed to me the most. The woman says she doesn't make much money from them and has to look for markets wherever she can. Her employees seem much nicer than the people in the north, and most importantly, they are also much more open to strangers.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_07_1: In the east of the island, just beyond the charcoal pile and a large lake, rises a mountain fortress called 'Wolf's Den' by the locals. It is said to be ruled by a burgrave who reclaimed it from its previous owner years ago. I tried to learn more about the history of this fortress, but the people I met nearby were silent and unwilling to talk. I had the impression that they were afraid of something.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_07_2: Although the fortress looked old at first sight, one could feel a certain majesty emanating from it - a reminder of past glory. The way through the gate was blocked by a stout sentry dressed in full armor from head to toe.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_07_3: He looked like a golem. He didn't take out the big axe on his back, but firmly ordered me to move back. I obeyed.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_07_4: Helmud, a builder who worked on the other side of the lake, told me that these warriors sometimes visited his outpost to see if the charcoal burners were doing their jobs properly. For what purpose? He would not say. He was reticent, just like the people of Wolf's Den. Or maybe he was just afraid of those  boneheads? If I were you, Reader, I would avoid this place by a wide margin.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_08_1: Although the Fire Mages have worked hard over the centuries to bring the people of Archolos to worship the one true deity they believe in, their efforts have been unsuccessful. The best proof of this is the monastery of Adanos, located in the eastern part of the island. At the request of my contractor, I went to the tabernacle to personally see to the transportation of the goods. However, I could not refrain from looking around.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_08_2: The monastery complex truly outshines even the palace building in my homeland! I'm sure that this work of architecture could not have been made by a mortal.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_08_3: The building rises on two islands - the larger one, which houses the shelter and wings for Water Mages and novices, and the smaller one, intended for members of the High Council.
WrittenText_ArcholosTravel_08_4: The Mages live a modest life, despite the great power they surely possess. They spend most of their time praying and teaching the novices. Unlike their counterparts in the city, they do not beg for donations for the Church, but try to be self-sufficient by planting herbs and vegetables. By day, the monastery is impressive, but its true beauty will be seen once the sun goes down. The eerie crystals along the pathways illuminate the shrouded sanctuary, glowing all shades of blue.
WrittenText_WakeUp_2: Day after day, the southern PLAGUE is infecting our city!
WrittenText_WakeUp_3: These are strangers who do not understand our faith, culture and traditions.
WrittenText_WakeUp_4: These unscrupulous BARBARIANS were murdering our boys at the front not so long ago, and today Morris is handing out gold, assigning jobs and building homes for them without a single reason!
WrittenText_WakeUp_5: Where is the law? Where is JUSTICE!
WrittenText_WakeUp_6: Where authority fails, the people must take matters into their own hands!
WrittenText_ThiefMaster_1: They may have gotten me, but I managed to secure my treasures.
WrittenText_ThiefMaster_2: In addition to the elaborate lock, I made sure that the door itself was unbreakable.
WrittenText_ThiefMaster_3: Only a true king of thieves could get inside.
WrittenText_ThiefMaster_4: No one will lay their hands on my chest!
WrittenText_MorrisLetter_02_1: The situation is dramatic. The army group 'Borderlands' has been broken.
WrittenText_MorrisLetter_02_2: Lee retreats south behind the river line towards Vengard. Hundreds, if not thousands of orcs are beginning sieges on more strongholds.
WrittenText_MorrisLetter_02_3: The gates of our citadels are thick, but if they bring in battering rams, I don't know how long they will hold off these savages.
WrittenText_MorrisLetter_02_4: This night I send another messenger. I hope he can break through the enemy's lines. This letter and copies of it must reach the king and the governors of the overseas colonies. It is time to prepare for the worst.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_01_1: On the fifth day of our journey, together with brother Alatar, I reached the shores of Archolos. Brothers Modares and Taneris welcomed us ... master Periandes with brother Corax went to talk with ... the lord who bears the name of Volfzack, which in the local tongue means a ‘son of a wolf’.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_01_2: People showed us great hospitality ... each of us a bowl full of fish ... The meal was reinforcing. In return, we blessed the generous people and ... the problem of the prowling beast ... Brother Modares decided to stay for a couple more days ... make sure that the villagers are safe.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_01_3: The village of Archolos reminds me of a small town. The inhabitants ... with the skill equal to the best carpenters in Myrtana. Volfzack invited us to his hall. On ... hanged ornate tapestries ... under the roof we saw ... and weapons forged from a black ... Our feet trotted on the hides of trolls and even larger, terrible ...
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_01_4: Master Periandes as a token of reconciliation, gave Volfzack a ... The chieftain hanged it proudly above ... and promised to never part with it. In return, he allowed us ... on a rocky cape on the northwest part of the island. There we shall erect a chapel to the Lord.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_02_1: Although wind-torn, ragged rocks of the remote cape do not ... hospitality as people from the island, thanks to our deep faith and determination, we built a chapel in honour of Adanos. Most of his time, master Periandes ... on prayer and meditations ... that the true purpose of our arrival remains hidden from servants of the Older Brothers.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_02_2: Brother Corax believes that Volfzack grew humble since our last visit in his hall. He believes ... which he was given with, but master Periandes constantly repeats that we all should give thanks to Adanos. Yesterday we were visited by Volfzack and his oldest son, Korvan.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_02_3: Stripped of their garments in which they had once greeted us, ... our guests were clothed now only in simple mantles. They wanted to learn the way of our Lord, and we, doing his bidding, filled their hearts ... two of his older sons, the court and greatest warriors. It was a great day, indeed, at the end of which our Lord himself wept tears of joy!
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_02_4: Our master, and in truth, the prior Periandes, in his wisdom decided that my task and the task of brother Alatar on this island are complete. And so we prepared our boats for a further journey east. We bid farewell to our brothers and I left this chronicle for my brother, Demas.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_03_1: Years passed and Adanos found its place in the hearts of people of this island for good. Many of them abandoned their earthly life and followed the path of righteousness and order. Thanks to the generosity of Volfzack and his sons, the monastery ... with quarters for mages and novices. Illness has struck prior Periandes and squeezes the life out of him like a skilled farmer squeezes juice off a bunch of grapes. We prayed for his recovery and sent for brother Taneris, an unrivalled medic.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_03_2: Last night prior Periandes passed away. Our Lord in his mercy spared him pain. Sad days have come to the Water Circle.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_03_3: Brothers Corax, Taneris, and Modares had the ... of guiding the High Council until a new shepherd of our stock is chosen. I shall write no more, for sorrow took away my ability to think clearly.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_03_4: Brother Modares, like he always does, departed on a pilgrimage across the island, searching for traces of the Lord in ... shrines, stone circles, and places of power. Master Taneris, however, is searching for him amongst the ancient ruins on the bogs. As they say, all the wisdom tends to come after the injury, yet nobody is surprised by their decisions. The Lord puts our faith to a test, indeed.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_04_1: Master Corax was proclaimed a new prior of the monastery. His promotion coincided with the Days of Mercy, during which Adanos forgives sins of sheep that went astray ... We still heard no word from brothers Taneris and Modares. Everyone hopes that with the Lord’s will, their journey shall end happily, and they return stronger in faith.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_04_2: In his generosity, brother Corax donated a great deal of the monastery fortune to erect shrines of Adanos on the island. To our joy, people eagerly helped us build them. Indeed, the faith in the Lord is strong with them. Words of the endeavour also reached the ears of brother Taneris.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_04_3: A great sorrow fell upon us, however, when we heard he abandoned our brotherhood. Brother Modares also returned this month from his own venture but decided to take roots in the village at the basin of the Silver River.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_04_4: Nothing in this world lasts forever, and Adanos constantly reminds us of it. We heard the sad news about the passing of Volfzack, the ruler of Archolos. We conducted the last rites for his soul and put his body to eternal rest in the tomb on the western end of the island. By Volfzack’s last will, his three sons, Korvan, Jarund, and Farkand shall now rule Archolos. May merciful Adanos guide them through the path of righteousness and order.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_05_1: Before the body of Volfzack was cold, his two sons, Jarund and Farkand were at each other’s throats, tearing apart their father’s legacy. The war they waged shook the foundations of Archolos and poisoned the hearts of its people. The age of pain and horror has begun. The age when brothers and sisters would betray each other and all teachings of Adanos would be forgotten.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_05_2: Seeing the futility of our attempts of negotiating with the battling brothers, the prior has called for a council to look for a solution to the worsening situation on the island. The vast majority of our brothers spoke up for restraint. We did not leave, however, the victims of the war to their fate.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_05_3: With the permission of the High Council, master Ladris, shall build a sanitarium. Brother Ezran, who was sent to the town for necessary materials, brought us sad news. The Lord took brother Modares. People say he perished in flames after saving several families from a burning house.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_05_4: Last night, the storm washed the cape, flooding the only path joining the mainland with the monastery. We understood this symbol in the only possible way. Beliar took hold of Archolos, and we must let him fulfill its destruction, so the process of renewal can begin.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_06_1: When Beliar feasted, plunging the land in chaos and destruction, Maximus, the King of Myrtana and the servant of Innos, arrived. Like a glowing blade in the sky, he pierced through the forces of the two brothers, gaining advantage in the conflict which in fact is a battle of the War of the Gods waged since the dawn of time.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_06_2: Farkand asked us for help, but we must not ignore the evident signs of the Lord. Adanos, in His vast wisdom, foresaw that in the hour of trial envoys of His brothers shall visit us, and they must be shunned. We have to wait when the time is right to bring balance and complete the cycle that was started.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_06_3: One day black clouds gathered over the west, and from the bowels of the sky came ribbons of the living fire which brought death upon Myrtanians and Wolf Sons alike. For many days the inferno consumed everything it found on its way, but our prayers begged Adanos to bring rain on His suffering children.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_06_4: Although Jarund still took hold of the eastern citadel, the forces of Maximus were too thinned to bleed again. And so the King of Myrtana signed a treaty, allowing the Wolf Sons to keep their dignity and the scraps of freedom. Many people sought refuge at our gates, and we, according to the Lord’s teachings, took them under our roof.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_07_1: With Maximus’ victory, the faith of Innos began to expand rapidly across Archolos. But people did not follow their dogmas willingly. It was instilled in them with force and fear by the king’s envoys. Following the prior’s advice, brothers Ladris, Arrian, Gordian, and Ordius set off to the four corners of the island to protect with a word and, if need be, with a deed, our stock from the wrath of the believers of Innos.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_07_2: When the new Myrtanian rule began to settle in Archolos, brother Ezran decided to erect a temple of Adanos in the town harbour. Despite many protests of dignitaries, after long negotiations, governor Godfrey consented to build it.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_07_3: He did not expect, however, that the faith of our Lord’s stock would be so strong. Day after day, more and more believers would come at its door.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_07_4: But Maximus’ heart burnt with jealousy, and so the war over the faith on Archolos was far from over. Shortly after, armed men stepped into the temple, depraved our sacred place, and seized many of the faithful. Innos himself must have seen this evil, as he brought fire upon the town hall, whose flames could be quenched only by soothing drops of the spring rain.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_08_1: Many years after the death of Maximus, despite the hatred which still burned bright in people’s hearts, followers of Adanos and Innos learned how to live together in peace. When the servants of the God of Light took hold over the town, believers of the Lord of Order would crowd in villages, forests, and on the shore of the sea. With that, the process of restoration was fulfilled, and the balance on Archolos was preserved. As a sign of conciliation, we decided to lay foundations for the bridge meant to rejoin the monastery with the mainland.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_08_2: Brothers of the High Council unanimously voted for appointing Water Ring, the armed unit of the monastery.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_08_3: From the selected people, a group of warriors has been chosen. These stalwart men showed extraordinary strength of spirit and skill. From this day forward, they shall maintain balance on Archolos.
WrittenText_ArcanumMarum_08_4: Rejoice, for Adanos blessed us with a new shepherd of our stock! Brother Regen, who had been studying for many years under the late master Myzon, became the leader of the monastery at the age of thirty-three. May the Lord watch over him and guide through the meanders of balance, and protect him from lies and wickedness of this world.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_01_1: After the death of Volfzack, the legendary founder of Archolos, according to the will of the deceased, the power on the island was divided among his three sons.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_01_2: The eldest son, Korvan, took control of the city and the surrounding territories. The younger son, Jarund obtained the old fortress to the west and the mountain citadel to the east. Farkand, the youngest of Volfzack's sons, received fertile lands near the Silver River.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_01_3: Despite their blood ties, Volfzack's primal fire, which made him the ruler of the Eastern Archipelago, began to burn in their hearts.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_01_4: Following his father's footsteps, Korvan built a vast fleet meant to bring the world to heel. He left the throne to his governor, who soon lost it to Jarund. His domination of the island, however, was opposed by Farkand, who was the only one of the three brothers to faithfully carry out his father's will in an effort to maintain the fragile peace on the island.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_01_5: With the onset of the Great Winter, a period of unrest began, culminating in a bloody conflict that echoes to this day among the people of this part of the world.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_02_1: The relative peace did not last long. One night, a group of armed men ransacked Jarund's farms. Most of the crops were burned and the livestock slaughtered. Supposing that Farkand's soldiers were behind the attack, Jarund responded with a firm and powerful strike against his brother's guardhouses. His warriors, however, had no difficulty in doing so, for they outnumbered their opponents in numbers, weapons, and training. Just days after the conflict began, Farkand was pushed back to the Silver River line.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_02_2: The younger brother had no choice but to rely on outside help to fend off the crushing northern forces.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_02_3: A few months after the war began, a Farkand emissary arrived at Londram's court with a request for support. The king of the island, mindful of the wrongs Volfzack had once inflicted on his father, made high demands. In the event of victory over Jarund, he was to claim the throne of Archolos, which after his death would pass to his sons until the end of time.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_02_4: Farkand found it difficult to agree to the Londramian king's ultimatum, risking both his authority and the future of the island. He knew, however, that if he did not, Jarund would prevail in this war and bury their father's dream of eternal peace.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_03_1: With the onset of the Great Winter, the front line shifted slightly to the Northern Tract. Jarund, however, did not easily surrender to his brother. He was able to resist thanks to three companies of swarthy mercenaries he brought from the island of Glenwyr, north of Archolos.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_03_2: The offensive of the combined forces of Farkand and Londramians, at first moving like a storm, slowed to a halt on the outskirts of the city and the fortress of Vardhal.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_03_3: Deprived of supplies Jarund, however, still had enough reserves to successfully hold the siege for months. Farkand, on the other hand, though in control of the fields, was unable to exploit their riches due to the advancing winter.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_03_4: When the outcome of the war seemed to be at a standstill, black smoke rose over the northern bay, and with it could be smelled the stench of burning wood. It was the Londramian fleet that was in flames. The scouts, however, did not see the wolf banners of the long-awaited Korvan, but the pennants of Myrtana's overseas king Maximus III the Conqueror.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_04_1: The first blow of the Myrtanian hammer fell on the small coast in the north of the island, manned by Jarund's forces. It was there that one of the bloodiest battles of the war took place between the vanguard of the royal army and the mercenaries of Glenwyr. Despite the element of surprise and overwhelming odds on the Myrtanians' side, Jarund's men held off waves of royal paladins all day until the last defender was dead. The Northern Tract was then opened to Maximus.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_04_2: Having destroyed Londram's fleet, Farkand knew that sooner or later he would have to face an overseas force. He also knew that he could not defeat the Myrtanian army in the open field. So he decided to resort to trickery and lured Lord Ottmar's contingent to the Crow's Pass, a small rocky passage to the south. The moment the paladins and royal guardsmen were in the gorge, Farkand's scouts set off a trap, dropping an avalanche on the invaders. Many noble paladins then perished under the boulders and in the basin below. Despite high hopes, this move did not stop Ottmar from pushing Farkand further south.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_05_1: While the Myrtanian contingent pushed the enemy towards the Silver River, the 'Army North' commanded by the king himself besieged the city. Jarund suspected that Archolos would not hold out for long, so he fled through the sewers with his most loyal men. He hoped that the people left behind would delay the city's agony and give him time to prepare a counterattack. However, the volunteers, without a leader, were slaughtered by Myrtanians.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_05_2: The capture of Archolos undermined the morale of the feuding brothers.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_05_3: Jarund's emissaries repeatedly tried to convince Farkand to lay down his arms in the face of foreign invasion, but the wounds on both sides were too fresh for the people to forget their recent wrongs so easily.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_05_4: The Myrtanians showed warriors of Archolos the power of technology. Crossbows decimated troops of the king of Londram and sent him to the bottom of the Silver River. Farkand, alone and wounded, died at the hands of the knights. With the capturing of the city and the crushing of resistance in the south, the Myrtanians paved the way to the ancient fortress of Vardhal.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_06_1: The frost held for many months. Longer than any other in the memory of the people of Archolos. Winter was followed by spring, but as if in defiance of the order of nature, not a sprout grew from the ground strewn with corpses and soaked with blood. It was as if it itself knew that the worst was yet to come.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_06_2: And it was not wrong. For Maximus' and Jarund's soldiers were preparing for the biggest battle of the war. While Jarund was regrouping the remnants of his troops in the mountain citadel in the east, Maximus, having crushed the resistance in the south and captured the city, launched a full force assault on the fortress of Vardhal.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_06_3: Corpses were strewn thickly on both sides, and arrows and projectiles from ballistas and catapults constantly pierced the sky. Although the Myrtanians outnumbered the defenders in numbers and equipment, the defenders had excellent conditions to withstand even a siege of several years. The walls of Vardhal were thick and high, a narrow stone bridge led to the gate, and each tower had a stone-throwing mangonel. All it would have taken was for Vardec, commander of the Wolf Sons, to wait patiently for relief from the east, and Jarund would have had victory in hand.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_07_1: The starving and cold army of Maximus was a shadow of its former glory. The morale of the soldiers was crumbling, and the bravest of the brave began to believe that the expedition would soon end in their deaths.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_07_2: Maximus could not wait a moment longer. But he could not count on the unconditional devotion of his advisors either. The king's men had long been in doubt, not only about the expedition, but also about the king's policies.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_07_3: Maximus therefore sent for the mage Wirgilio, who had stood by his side since campaign started. He promised the king victory over the pagans provided that his soldiers proved worthy servants of the God of Fire. Maximus gave the orders.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_07_4: Wave after wave of guardsmen and paladins stormed the fortifications of Vardhal. When they reached its gates, the heavens lit up with a blood-red glow and the clouds spat out living fire, a fiery rain fell upon the fortress. Neither the steel of the armour nor the stone walls could resist it. It did not spare anyone.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_08_1: According to the story, the rain of fire lasted three days and three nights, but it only took a moment for the courtyard and the interior of the fortress to go up in flames. It is said that, horrified by the extent of the destruction, Maximus fell to his knees, clutching a statue of Innos in his hands. It was at that moment that the boastful king was said to have calmed down in the face of the power of the Fire God and fully offered Archolos to his protection.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_08_2: The fire continued to burn for many long days, until Adanos took pity on the hapless land, sending down soothing raindrops. The Myrtanians' victory came at a high price.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_08_3: The fire consumed most of the supplies, and there was not a trace of Volfzack's treasures and possessions. Some said that the fire was so powerful that the gold melted and flowed into the ground. Others claimed that the fire merely collapsed the passage to the stronghold, and that the treasures were still waiting for intrepid adventurers ready to discover them.
WrittenText_BrothersWar_08_4: Few sources about the Vardhal fire survived. Few have chosen to speak of it. Only the silent shadows that haunt the deserted corridors of the fortress continue to sing a quiet, somber song to this day.
WrittenText_Meatbugs_1: Rich merchants, landowners and officials have been whining at Volker's door for weeks for 'war relief'.
WrittenText_Meatbugs_2: By what right do these MEATBUGS in human skin have the right to ask for alms when the common folk are starving?
WrittenText_Meatbugs_3: WE, the sons and daughters of this land, in the fields, mines and workshops shed blood, sweat and tears day after day for these privileged bastards!
WrittenText_Meatbugs_4: We call upon all those who hunger for justice in these very unjust times. It is time to say ENOUGH!
WrittenText_AgeOfCreation_1: In the first days of the world, before lands rose from the bottom of the sea, all things were covered by the immeasurable light which bound the creation processes. Aeons have passed, and the undivided Eternal Light solitary ruled over all existence.
WrittenText_AgeOfCreation_2: And so Eternal Light gave sway to Eternal Darkness.
WrittenText_AgeOfCreation_3: The foundations of the universe trembled, and the life-giving energy of creation reached its farthest
WrittenText_AgeOfCreation_4: corners and gave motion to celestial bodies, which began to swirl around the source of Eternal Darkness called Morgrad. Together with the energy, from the black recesses of the abyss, four elements - earth, water, fire, and wind - were released.
WrittenText_AgeOfCreation_5: But Eternal Darkness, like Eternal Light, alone could not bring life into the world. And so from the depths of Morgrad came the sun, which warmed the dark and cold crust of the primordial world. Ages passed before the elements of water and earth breathed life into dry valleys and rocky recesses, filling them with water, and rose mountains from which spurted life-giving rivers.
WrittenText_AgeOfLife_1: When in a primordial world, lands and waters found its place, the power of creation gave birth to plants and animals. As on the order of the fire element, still rising mountains trembled, and spit flames which enriched dead soil. Then, river basins became covered with grass, and mountain valleys with forests.
WrittenText_AgeOfLife_2: Depths and shores of the sea, plains and woods were filled with game of all sorts, and each of them found its place on the ruthless, but ironic wheel of life.
WrittenText_AgeOfLife_3: A wolf would always dominate the sheep, and a bear was always stronger than a wolf. At the end of their lives, each of them would become nothing more than meatbugs’ food.
WrittenText_AgeOfLife_4: But, when life flourished on the east, on the west it withered. Yet then, the energy of creation brought wind into the world which pushed clouds over the farthest wastes of the west, changing them into vibrant warm forests. Thus, the last of the elements of Morgrad arrived.
WrittenText_AgeOfLife_5: When plants and animals became one with the world, the energy of creation gave birth to a human.
WrittenText_AgeOfMiracle_1: At last, to the world came the Gods, destined to rule over the whole work of Morgrad. Life and death. Creation and destruction. Thus, they reigned supreme over the world, and they taught humans nearly everything they knew.
WrittenText_AgeOfMiracle_2: To the gates of their stone cities hailed old and young, healthy and sick, and the masters of the world blessed them with wisdom and mercy. But one day, arrogance and vanity poisoned humans’ hearts. They wished to learn the Gods’ ultimate mystery. Knowledge of creating life.
WrittenText_AgeOfMiracle_3: They opened the gates of Morgrad, hoping to find answers to their questions. But behind the door of the untold void, they found night, and with it, death stepped into the world. Since then, every human one day had to look in the eyes of the indifferent finality.
WrittenText_AgeOfMiracle_4: Afraid of the destructive power of their own making, the Gods decided to leave this world, never to return. They left humans a figment of their own power meant to lead them through the darkness that was yet to come. Thus magic came to this world, and the Age of Wonders came to an end.
WrittenText_AgeOfGods_1: Ages passed, and humans, broken and abandoned, stepped off the path of righteousness and order, and awakened in themselves the primal instincts of their ancestors. In endless wars, brothers and sisters turned against themselves, until the whole memory of the old teachings has been forever lost.
WrittenText_AgeOfGods_2: Humans began to erect shrines in honour of the Gods, looking for solace in the hour of woe. They prayed to Innos, the god of light and order, and Beliar, the lord of darkness and malice. Since then light and darkness, life and death, order and chaos would clash, poisoning mortal hearts.
WrittenText_AgeOfGods_3: But some did not accept such a matter of things. Builders, as they were called, tried to find the source of the true power of their masters. They knew that light and darkness have to coexist so that the process of creation can continue.
WrittenText_AgeOfGods_4: And so they sent the wisest of the wise to the four corners of the world to teach peoples the dogmas of order. And the worthiest of them were taught of magic, the greatest gift of the Gods.
WrittenText_InnosWill_01_1: Legends tell of a young man who came from beyond the jagged peaks of Nordmar to change the fate of the entire world. The boy was Rhobar, a fearless warrior in the service of the chief of one of the tribes of the later Borderlands.
WrittenText_InnosWill_01_2: On the eve of a battle with the enemy, the boy was visited by Innos himself, who inspired him to great deeds. Others say that the young man fought a terrifying beast sent by Beliar himself. But the Lord appeared to him and gave him a burning sword able to bring death to the monster. The next morning, the warrior led his men to a heroic victory.
WrittenText_InnosWill_01_3: Innos, in his immense wisdom, then guided the young man to the farthest reaches of the known world. Clad in a gray mantle, Rhobar began a long journey, illuminating the darkness of backwardness in the frozen wastes of the North and the scorching sands of the South.
WrittenText_InnosWill_01_4: Critics of his character claim that the boy's emergence was a coincidence; a confluence of circumstances and tribal conflicts that brought an end to the Old Faith on the continent. But would it have been a coincidence that the Kingdom of Myrtana, the most magnificent political entity, came into being? It was so by the will of Innos himself.
WrittenText_InnosWill_02_1: Upon arriving in his homeland, Rhobar found the once united land once again bathed in blood and chaos. The old leader and his entourage had been murdered and Ahalt, known as the Bloodsucker, took over. Notorious for his blasphemous rituals, the northern barbarian ordered Rhobar captured and punished, but he escaped in time with a group of followers.
WrittenText_InnosWill_02_2: For days he tirelessly went from village to village, preparing the people for battle. As it turned out, Ahalt had taken power by force, while most of the people remained loyal to the old order in secret.
WrittenText_InnosWill_02_3: They recognized the leader in Rhobar and soon stood with him in front of the usurper's stronghold, demanding he return power. Ahalt then set a trap in motion.
WrittenText_InnosWill_02_4: Some of Rhobar's warriors were bribed by the usurper and dealt his men a severe blow in the back. It was then that the gates of the stronghold burst open and the barbarians attacked. However, Innos did not abandon his children. A fiery glow lit the blackened sky, bringing a ball of fire to the battlefield, burning the traitors and followers of Ahalt to the ground. The battle was won.
WrittenText_InnosWill_03_1: People saw Rhobar as the divine anointed, and crowned him the first king of Myrtana, a country formed from the confederation of tribes converted to the faith of Innos. The new ruler knew that it was faith which bound the hearts of men together in one common purpose. For this reason, he formed a group of wise men - people with the power granted by the Lord himself. With time, this group evolved into the Circle of Fire Mages.
WrittenText_InnosWill_03_2: Upon hearing of Rhobar's coronation, wanderers came to the eastern shores of the continent to worship Adanos, the god of water, order and balance.
WrittenText_InnosWill_03_3: Despite the efforts of the worshippers, the faith gained popularity mainly among the rural and coastal populations. Rhobar did not ban the new religion, however, but rather, like a good host, welcomed its practitioners into his home.
WrittenText_InnosWill_03_4: Over the next years, the king fought countless battles, ensuring the security of the country's still fluid borders. At the Battle of the Black Creek, he curbed the conquering ways of the Varrantian warlord, and through his patient negotiations he brought peace to Borderlands. At the end of his reign, Rhobar brought the kingdom under the protection of Innos, sealing the Supreme's role in shaping Myrtanian identity.
WrittenText_InnosWill_04_1: Many years after Rhobar's death, successive rulers strove to live up to his reputation, but with mixed results.
WrittenText_InnosWill_04_2: Prince Ulthwar, the Unworthy, decided to waste nearly half of his life implementing a plan to return to the roots. During his time, temples were closed and people were told to pray to trees. Because of this, many dangerous, long-extinct cults were also resurrected.
WrittenText_InnosWill_04_3: King Alaric, called Godfearing, was Ulthwar's grandson and his opposite. He rekindled the flame of faith among the people of Myrtana, and returned to the Church the goods stolen by his grandfather.
WrittenText_InnosWill_04_4: However, he wasted most of his reign chasing domestic enemies, constantly looking for plots against his own life.
WrittenText_InnosWill_04_5: There was also Gunther, known as the Drunkard. During his reign, people joked: 'there is more wine floating around the court than intrigues!' - for the king's main concern was to rush the cupbearers and make regular tours of the vineyards. Of course, at taxpayers' expense.
WrittenText_InnosWill_04_6: Changes came only with the accession of King Domenico, who was the first to look eastwards, towards the vast sea that separated Myrtana from the new lands full of treasures and mysteries.
WrittenText_InnosWill_05_1: King Domenico was regarded as a man of the people. Instead of sitting in elegant chambers and receiving guests, he preferred to spend his days in taverns listening to captivating tales of sailors and fishermen. It is believed that his passion for adventure gave birth to his urge to travel.
WrittenText_InnosWill_05_2: However, this was no mere whim of yet another noble, but a deliberate policy to expand borders of Myrtana. Domenico poured a large part of his treasury into the construction of a huge fleet which, according to its captains, was meant to ‘touch the horizon’.
WrittenText_InnosWill_05_3: Although sailors never made it there, they established numerous settlements on Khorinis, Laran, Eritros and the Southern Islands, which over the years grew into thriving trading posts.
WrittenText_InnosWill_05_4: Overloaded frigates filled to the brim with red pepper, animal skins, tobacco and magic ore, made their way to Myrtanian ports, increasing wealth and prestige of merchants with each passing month.
WrittenText_InnosWill_05_5: With the spark that Domenico ignited in the hearts of his people, Myrtana became a seafaring kingdom.
WrittenText_InnosWill_06_1: Having reached a ripe old age, Domenico I, known as the Sailor, retired to the bosom of Innos and was succeeded by his son, Albrecht. The young king inherited from his father a state that was rich and constantly expanding its borders.
WrittenText_InnosWill_06_2: However, Albrecht suffered from a terrible disease, which slowly but steadily wore away at his body. Many assumed that he would not live to see his thirtieth birthday. Many also tried unsuccessfully to find a cure. Barbers argued with each other in daring theories, and brought astronomers consulted the stars.
WrittenText_InnosWill_06_3: The ruler did not wait until disease takes him. He knew that strong and well-equipped soldiers were the guarantee of Myrtana's safety. He decided to reform his conscript army to a professional one, and built a line of forts on the border with Nordmar.
WrittenText_InnosWill_06_4: Albrecht was the first king of Myrtana to recognize the value of the magic ore mined on the island of Khorinis. Its strength and magical properties were to give his army an advantage. However, not many smiths could shape the ore, so the ruler allocated it only to the needs of the paladins.
WrittenText_InnosWill_07_1: King Albrecht, having no heir, passed the crown to his nephew, Maximus. The young ruler received from his uncle a strong and prosperous kingdom. Or so it seemed.
WrittenText_InnosWill_07_2: As shipping grew, the aristocracy craved rights to new colonies, their own armies, and wider freedoms beyond the mainland Myrtana. They incited the people against the king, but he consistently nipped their claims in the bud.
WrittenText_InnosWill_07_3: Maximus had no easy nut to crack. There were plenty of advisors at Vengard's court, but they only looked at things from a self-interested perspective.
WrittenText_InnosWill_07_4: The King heard the advice of each, but only listened to the Archmage of Fire, Ferrus.
WrittenText_InnosWill_07_5: The priest said that nothing unites people like a common enemy, so he proposed that the king organize an expedition to the lands in the east, where the torch of Innos had not yet reached. He assigned his most faithful disciple, Wirgilio, to assist him in this noble work.
WrittenText_InnosWill_07_6: Maximus put everything on the line. Leaving power in the hands of the Mages of Fire and Water, the ambitious ruler set out for the Eastern Archipelago at the head of a large army.
WrittenText_InnosWill_08_1: After two weeks of travel, Maximus’ forces landed on the island of Archolos, right in the middle of the bloody conflict later known as the War of the Two Brothers. Following the death of Volfzack, the first ruler of the land, his two sons Jarund and Farkand were at each other's throats, shedding the blood of thousands within a year.
WrittenText_InnosWill_08_2: The first Myrtanian attack fell on the northwestern coast of the island. Welcomed by the rain of arrows, paladins clashed with hosts of Glenwyr. At the same time, the fleet blockaded the harbor, and from the west, troops advanced up the Silver River.
WrittenText_InnosWill_08_3: Although warriors of Archolos were many, Myrtanians had better equipment. Armed with swords of magic ore paladins obliterated barbarian hosts. They were supported by the famous crossbow battalion of Captain Carrizo.
WrittenText_InnosWill_08_4: During the campaign, Maximus proved his tactical genius by dividing his army into three groups and effectively coordinating their actions. When the king eliminated Farkand's forces, archmage Wirgilio was the one who sealed Myrtana's victory. Inspired by the words of Innos himself, he brought a rain of fire upon the fortress of Vardhal, Jarund's main point of resistance.
WrittenText_InnosWill_09_1: After his victory on Archolos, Maximus was criticised by aristocracy. Many considered the expedition to be a whim of a young king who had become overwhelmed by his duties at home. The conquest itself was a sign of barbarism. In retrospect, Maximus could not have made a better decision.
WrittenText_InnosWill_09_2: The intervention on Archolos not only converted the inhabitants to the faith in Innos, but also developed them civilizationally. Mediocre administration was replaced by the tried and tested Myrtanian system, and the moribund economy was revived by trade routes.
WrittenText_InnosWill_09_3: Within less than a year Maximus III, called the Conqueror, had colonized the neighboring island of Londram and established outposts on distant Contira. With the conquest of nearly the entire Eastern Archipelago, many merchants began to form unions and guilds to protect their common interests. The golden age of trade on the Myrtana Sea began.
WrittenText_InnosWill_09_4: Maximus' overseas victories did not bring him much popularity on the continent. The growing internal and external problems were also not helped by the fact that the king spent most of his reign abroad.
WrittenText_InnosWill_10_1: Many historians argue that Maximus could have prevented the rebellion by keeping soldiers in the colonies, who would have restrained the merchants' with fear or force. Others believe that it was King Domenico who directly laid the groundwork for the conflict by building a huge fleet.
WrittenText_InnosWill_10_2: However, it was only after Maximus' expedition that the merchants saw their opportunity. More and more they steered the course of trade in colonies. In time, they began to meddle with politics, enlist armies and introduce their own coinage. Many unions were then formed, which, under the banner of the Eastern League, renounced obedience to the king.
WrittenText_InnosWill_10_3: To the end of his days, Maximus believed that he would be able to appease the merchants. However, the negotiations failed every time. It was not until his son, Mandred the Grim, decided to use force. Out of high but necessary taxes, the king raised an army and moved it east.
WrittenText_InnosWill_10_4: Although the League had an excellent fleet, in less than a few months of fighting it lost control of most of its ports and its leaders were punished accordingly. Mandred restored peace to the colonies and established the only legitimate merchant organization, the Guild of Araxos.
WrittenText_InnosWill_11_1: Mandred's victory over the Eastern League strengthened the Kingdom of Myrtana in every way. Trade, which had previously been a gray area, came under strict control, and any signs of rebellion in the colonies were swiftly suppressed by trained and well-equipped city guards.
WrittenText_InnosWill_11_2: The increased number of soldiers and the centralization of power, while stabilizing the country internally, had no effect on the situation outside the borders of the kingdom. The Varrantians repeatedly violated the peace treaty, and the Nordmarians viewed the line of forts erected in the Borderlands with suspicion.
WrittenText_InnosWill_11_3: Some critics charged that Mandred risked too much to destabilize the country by planning war with Nordmar after the discovery of magic ore there. These plans, if they were indeed in the making, were put on hold by the sinking of a ship with the prince aboard.
WrittenText_InnosWill_11_4: Learning that corsairs from the Southern Islands were behind his son's death, the enraged Mandred began preparations for war, sending nearly all of his troops into the conflict. The conflict with the Southerners lasted many months, but despite small victories and the steadfastness of the Myrtanians, the king suffered irreparable losses and had to demand a retreat in disgrace.
WrittenText_InnosWill_12_1: When the bells in Vengard announced Mandred's death, mutineers led by Florens, the head of an aristocratic family from southern Myrtana, attempted to seize power. The rebels stormed the throne room, taking members of the Royal Council hostage. The coup failed, however, and the Fire and Water Mages managed to regain control.
WrittenText_InnosWill_12_2: The Archmages once again seized power, making decisions with the support of the Council. This reign was not an easy one. Chronic droughts caused famine and with it came disease.
WrittenText_InnosWill_12_3: The villages near the border with Varrant became the target of regular raids from the south and bands of Nordmarians started to plunder the Borderlands. The troubled people longed for the impossible - the return of the King to the throne of Myrtana.
WrittenText_InnosWill_12_4: The Vengardian poet Widron described this time as the 'days of bile and decay' where all morality and compassion were forgotten. The rulers of Varrant and Nordmar took advantage of the chaos. By forming an alliance, they partitioned Myrtana, like vermin tearing apart this once beautiful land.
WrittenText_InnosWill_13_1: The hoofbeats of Varrantian cataphracts and the thud of Nordmarian boots could be heard from the Black Creek in the south to Siegburg in the north. Those who joined the invaders could enjoy life with the stigma of traitors, serving their new masters. For those who took up arms, awaited only death.
WrittenText_InnosWill_13_2: When the enemy reached Vengard, a miracle happened. Innos saved his children and turned the invaders against each other. In the meantime, a resistance organized by the archmages and led by a young officer rose up, liberating much of the country.
WrittenText_InnosWill_13_3: Just when there seemed to be a glimmer of hope the drums of war sounded again - this time from the west. Like a hateful wave, a horde of orcs swept across Myrtana, wreaking havoc. A young officer began an unequal fight with the enemy, gathering the inhabitants of the land under his banner.
WrittenText_InnosWill_13_4: The war lasted many years. Many lives were taken, and much of Myrtana was turned to ruin. However, the dedication of citizens managed to chase away the black clouds from the land hallowed by Innos, and the young leader, a symbol of hope and determination, was proclaimed as the new king of Myrtana - Rhobar II.
WrittenText_InnosWill_14_1: After the Great War with the Orcs, Rhobar II had to make many difficult but necessary decisions to ensure the integrity of the country.
WrittenText_InnosWill_14_2: From his colonies in the east, the king brought supplies and troops to defend Myrtana's borders. He also conquered a weakened Nordmar. This move, though criticized by Water Mages, gave the king access to valuable deposits of magic ore.
WrittenText_InnosWill_14_3: Rhobar's engineers developed a new kind of blackpowder weaponry. Soon the first cannons capable of hurling projectiles over long distances appeared on walls and ships.
WrittenText_InnosWill_14_4: The king sent brave paladins to the four corners of the world to rekindle the flame of Innos in the hearts of infidels.
WrittenText_InnosWill_14_5: Rhobar was the first ruler of Myrtana to invade Varrant. The forces of the south, led by the outstanding strategists Lukkor and Gellon, put up equal resistance to the Royal Guardsmen, but a brilliant maneuver by General Lee sealed the victory for the Myrtanians.
WrittenText_InnosWill_14_6: The people of the Kingdom of Myrtana, heartened and united, began to see more and more signs, portending the greater storm that was inevitably to come.
WrittenText_Araxos_01_1: From time immemorial man has longed to travel. No wonder, after all, they are embedded in our blood. Our ancestors already knew that expeditions are necessary to provide shelter and food for their loved ones. We were also driven by simple human curiosity. The desire to know what lies beyond the next hill, bay, and sea, caused our civilization to reach the limits of the currently known world.
WrittenText_Araxos_01_2: Travel, however, not only expanded our knowledge of different lands and their inhabitants, but also contributed to many discoveries in science and crafts. To travel across the vast seas, we had to learn navigation based on the position of the sun and stars in the sky.
WrittenText_Araxos_01_3: Sea voyages also required us to design and build sturdy boats and ships capable of carrying people and goods over long distances.
WrittenText_Araxos_01_4: Over the years, man began to see the benefits of frequent travel. It allowed us to season our meals with spicy red pepper and enjoy the sweetness of honeyed tobacco at the end of a workday. Travel also caused the establishment of settlements on newly discovered lands, where local business flourished. Over time, the people who settled there began to form trade associations, from which emerged the incomparable 'Araxos' merchant guild.
WrittenText_Araxos_02_1: Although today the leading in trade Araxos Guild and all its branches is an integral part of Myrtana, its origins are shrouded in a tumultuous conflict that challenged the economy of the kingdom for many years.
WrittenText_Araxos_02_2: When news of King Maximus III's conquest of the Eastern Archipelago spread around the world, the new colonies became a temptation for many merchants, whose ships flocked to the new colonies. As Berfeld, then scribe of the Archolos City Hall, wryly observed, 'there were days when I saw more frigates in the harbor than debtors in my account book!'
WrittenText_Araxos_02_3: The king was at first pleased with the benefits that the fledgling colonies brought to trade. No wonder. Trade was, after all, a kind of spark that lit a fire in the economically ossified Myrtanian stove. Leather, weapons, tobacco and jewels came to the east. To the west, ships laden with wine, silver, salt and textiles sailed.
WrittenText_Araxos_02_4: The plan, which at first bore fruit, began to turn against Maximus over time. The colonies, which were many miles away from Vengard, were more willing to accept the authority of the merchants than that of the king's envoys. The bolder, more self-sufficient posts, in turn, began to decide the economy and politics, and even minted their own coins.
WrittenText_Araxos_03_1: King Maximus’ attempts to negotiate with merchants proved futile. The sails of their ships were less and less decorated with Myrtana's emblems, and instead they bore the symbols of newly founded unions and guilds. At the gates of trading posts, one could find not vendors, but armed to the teeth mercenaries.
WrittenText_Araxos_03_2: Many blame King Domenico I for the outbreak of the rebellion, who years earlier had given traders a modern fleet. Although he undoubtedly gave the rebels the tools, the real initiator of the revolt was the wealthy merchant Delaverd.
WrittenText_Araxos_03_3: Upon hearing of new colonies in the east, he moved to them his fortune and began investing in local resources, which he taxed heavily.
WrittenText_Araxos_03_4: Delaverd soon became the most influential magnate in the Eastern Archipelago. The only thing that stood in his way of becoming a trade hegemon was the royal procedures, which significantly delayed the transport of goods on the continent. With the help of corsairs from local isles, Delaverd efficiently avoided the main merchant routes.
WrittenText_Araxos_04_1: As Maximus, opening the islands of the Eastern Archipelago to the world, threw the bait to the merchants, so Delaverd decided to grab the whole rod. One night he and the leaders of the influential merchant guilds signed a treaty creating the 'Eastern League', which effectively took control of the colonies. The effects of his decision, however, were lamentable for the continent.
WrittenText_Araxos_04_2: The royal treasury received only a fifth of the gold from the trade in goods, as a result of which the south of Myrtana was plagued by poverty, famine and disease. With time, people began to take to the streets of the cities, demanding decisive action from the authorities.
WrittenText_Araxos_04_3: Rebellions and executions of royal emissaries ensued, and the country was plunged into chaos for many years.
WrittenText_Araxos_04_4: Maximus was succeeded by his son, Mandred the Harsh, who vowed that he would not rest until the colonies returned to Myrtana. However, if the tales are to be believed, the real cause of the conflict was the dumping of an entire supply of swampweed into the sea before it reached the harbor of Vengard. The King, famous for his love of this once popular and legal stimulant, took the insult personally. War was inevitable.
WrittenText_Araxos_05_1: The emptiness of the treasury did not give Mandred hope for a quick conscription of an army and an effective offensive. The king then decided to pardon some of the convicts, whom he ordered to be trained and armed in the manner of knechts. This decision caused strong opposition in the ranks of professional soldiers and commanders, but all signs of rebellion were nipped in the bud.
WrittenText_Araxos_05_2: Despite the initial success of Mandred's campaign, the conflict stalled. The Eastern League, with its superior navy, easily won clashes at sea, cutting the Myrtanians off from regular supplies from the continent.
WrittenText_Araxos_05_3: On land, the king's unleashed soldiers brought order to the rebellious populace with fire and sword.
WrittenText_Araxos_05_4: Just when it seemed that neither side would be able to fully defeat the other, Mandred resorted to trickery. In a sham peace treaty with the governors of the Eastern League, Mandred used bribed merchants to slaughter his opponents, including Delaverd, putting an end to the rebellion.
WrittenText_Araxos_06_1: With the death of the mutiny's leaders during the infamous 'Red Pacts', the Eastern League ceased to exist and so did the archipelago's dreams of autonomy. By decree, King Mandred appropriated some of the ships and assets of the trade associations and replaced the League with the Guild of Araxos, subordinate to the kingdom.
WrittenText_Araxos_06_2: In addition, the ruler withdrew the coins minted by the merchants from circulation and established new trade routes, which from now on passed through checkpoints established by him. Although these decisions provided the kingdom with transparency in the circulation of goods, the economic losses were irreparable.
WrittenText_Araxos_06_3: Most of the goods being transported arrived at their destination spoiled or damaged as a result of long days at sea or overzealous searches. Ships were often damaged or pirated during the voyage, and Mandred, who was at war with the Southerners at the time, was reluctant to spend resources on saving trade.
WrittenText_Araxos_06_4: During the interregnum, and later the partition of Myrtana, the position of the Araxos Guild was bleak. Many of its trading posts were converted into hospitals for wounded soldiers and insurgents. In turn, the lack of an organized leadership and the divergence of policies brought more and more confusion to its ranks.
WrittenText_Araxos_07_1: After the Great War with the Orcs, Rhobar II became a symbol of the kingdom's reconstruction. A ray of sunshine in a land strewn with death. For the Araxos Guild, it was three entrepreneurs who were elected to the organization's governing body.
WrittenText_Araxos_07_2: Fernando chose the city of Khorinis as his headquarters. Thanks to his generous donations, the flow of magic ore from the Valley of Mines was improved.
WrittenText_Araxos_07_3: Lorenzo was given the title of chairman of the guild hall on Archolos. In a short time he restored it to its former glory and established a key trading post on Glenwyr.
WrittenText_Araxos_07_4: Reina, in turn, set out for the remote island of Laran. She erected a mining outpost in the vast marshes, a source of precious crystals.
WrittenText_Araxos_07_5: This ‘Elder Council,' gathers once a year with other influential Guild members to discuss matters of importance. Their meetings are always held in secret, and members are identified by carved rings made of special alloy.
WrittenText_Araxos_08_1: Not many years had passed when black clouds once again hung over the future of the Guild of Araxos. The Second War with the Orcs broke out, and after the collapse of the royal fleet at the Battle of the Eastern Archipelago, Rhobar II issued an edict claiming ownership of all ships in the seas - including merchant vessels.
WrittenText_Araxos_08_2: The efforts of Ronja, archivist at the Trading Post on Archolos, proved that as a result of this decision, the Guild of Araxos lost twenty hulks, sixteen carracks, eight frigates and five galleons to the king.
WrittenText_Araxos_08_3: Although The Elder Council succeeded in convincing the Myrtanian authorities of the need for mercenary units, the losses caused by the confiscation of the ships are no longer counted in tens but hundreds of carts of gold. Since the rumors of pirates and orc galleys constantly recur, it can be assumed that the golden age of trade is over. People increasingly say that colonies cut off from the world would rather drown in internal conflicts than restore their former power. On the lips of merchants and sailors, however, there is just as often an old sailor's proverb:
WrittenText_Araxos_08_4: As long as the breeze blows, the blue sails of Araxos will flutter on the seas of the world.
WrittenText_HistoryOfCity_01_1: The first records about the town known as ‘Holos’, meaning ‘everything that surrounds us’ date back many years before Volfzack's birth. The prefix ‘Arc’ (‘kingly’) was added when he became king. We can assume that the name ‘Archolos’ means ‘kingdom’.
WrittenText_HistoryOfCity_01_2: Years before, island was home to many tribes. Volfzack, leader of the mountain tribe, wanted to end the era of conflict. He challenged the ruler of Archolos to a fight, which ended as soon as it started. Seeing their leader fall, people proclaimed Volfzack a king.
WrittenText_HistoryOfCity_01_3: During the reign of ‘Wolf of Archolos’, the settlement consisted of nothing more than several clay-made huts and even fewer wooden houses inhabited by the rich.
